column1: Turek [ˈturɛk] is a town in central Poland with 31
column2: 282 inhabitants as of 2009. It is the capital of Turek County.

column1: Turek has been situated in the Greater Poland Voivodeship since 1999; it was in Konin Voivodeship from 1975 to 1998.
Turek is first mentioned in the historical record 1136
column2: when it was listed as belonging to the archbishops of Gniezno. It received its city rights in 1341. Administratively it was located in the Kalisz Voivodeship in the Greater Poland Province of the Polish Crown.

column1: Turek was annexed by Prussia in 1793 in the Second Partition of Poland
column2: regained by Poles and included within the short-lived Duchy of Warsaw in 1807
column3: and included within so-called Congress Poland in 1815
column4: soon forcibly integrated with the Russian Empire. It was then capital of a district within the Kalisz Governorate. Following the end of the First World War in 1918
column5: Turek became part of the Second Polish Republic as the country regained independence.

column1: With the German invasion of Poland and the outbreak of the Second World War in September 1939
column2: Turek was occupied by the Wehrmacht and annexed by Nazi Germany. It was administered as part of the county or district (kreis) of Turek within Reichsgau Wartheland. The Polish population was subjected to expulsions
column4: deportations to Nazi concentration camps and murder. In autumn of 1939
column5: the Einsatzgruppe VI carried out a number of executions of Poles at the local market. Teachers from Turek were among Polish teachers murdered in the Mauthausen concentration camp. The first expulsion of 160 Poles was carried out in December 1939
